bibl.title: Letter from H.M. Scheiffelin to William H. Seward
Notes from Liberian Legation In U.S. to Department of State, 1862-1898 T807

correspAction.roleName: The Secretary of State of the United States of America

div1.p: Sir I have the honor to announce to you for the informaton of the government of the United States of America, the fact, that too the Terri- torial jurisdiction of this Republic, commencing on the Northwest at the River Long
Honorable Hamilton Fish Secretary of State of the United State of America Washington

be made to yield the greatest amount of benefit to both governments. He considers that the affinity of the respective governments should encourage a disposition to strengthen this realtion when an opportunity offers, so as to secure the mutual advantages which tis calculated to promote. He is not forgetful in this solicitation of the disparity, in point of ability, between the government Liberia, the offspring, and that of the mother Republic.
Nevertheless he is of the opinion that the capability of Liberia to administer importantly to the commerce of the United States would justify an arrangement between the two governments by which they
they could be mutually benefited to an unprecedented extent.
These considerations have prompted the President of Liberia to direct, that an inquiry be enactt respectfully communicated to Your Excellency of the following character.

Whether the commercial transactions of the citizens of the United States with Liberians might not be expanded by a proper discrimination between the products of free and slave labor in the form of a moderation of the duties on sugar, coffee, canwood and Palm Oil imported into the United States by Liberian vessels on the vessels of citizens of the

United States. Second. Whether in view of the necessity in Liberia of the proper class of immigrants to build up and strengthen her, and to contribute to the development of her resources and in view of the necessity of the emigration of the colored people of the United States the government of the U. States would consent to facilitate an undertaking by LIberia to attract and bring to her shores, such of these people as might be willing to emigrate.
Referring to the first querry, it is only necessary to invite Your Excellency's attention to these facts: that the commerce of Libera, yet in its inciperiency, cannot,

cannot, ofr some years, render the influence of a competition witht he products of older states, especially those of slave labor, because as vigorous and profitable as it would that the work of enfranchisement and the abrogation of the slave trade,m in which the government of the United States takes preeminentlly the lead, would be promoted by the difficulty of introducing the products of slave labor into the U. States; and the fact, known too all to be named, that the government of H.R. Majesty impose no duty on Palm Oil introduced into her dominions
dominions from the Coast of Africa.

On the subject of the account query, it is proper to remark that the difficulty of procurring a class of immigrants much needed in the whole country, and especially to occupy contested points clearly within the political jurisdiction of the Republic of Liberia, will constrain the government of Liberia, herself, to invite an emigrate them by the permission and aid of the Mother Republci.
With sentiments of the highest consideration. I have the honor to be Your Excellency's most obedient servant
